Welcome to the
Kingdom of Dreams and Madness

Thank you for being here! This is a speculative project that dabbles in the creation of a new medium to help us think about exceedingly complex, urgent problems. On the surface, the project gives people an interactive, virtual world to explore and experiment with. Interactive toy-like features are designed as a more tangible representation of a 'model world' whose characteristics of interest are simulated in a fully operational, systems-based mathematical model. The juxtaposition of playful visuals and simulation-orientated modelling is proposed as the foundation for a new type of dynamic medium.

This initial prototype scratches the surface of new narrative opportunities, some which play around with new(ish) web technologies that are accessible from the humble browser. More polished and sophisticated ideas will be explored and added. The hope is that this dynamic medium inspires radically different kinds of authorship: one that enables complex content with nuanced narratives to be published in a form that activates new and enlightened ways of thinking...

This project is optimised for viewing in landscape orientation.

This prototype demonstrates how a narrative about climate change and community action might play out in a new dynamic medium. Admittedly, this prototype fails to explore some of the more radical aspirations for what a dynamic medium could do, but it's a start. Importantly, the topic being explored - climate change - is not the real focus of this project, but used as an example 'problem' to build a tangible prototype.

To explore this prototype you can access the "story mode" menu from the button in the top left of the screen. "Quick access" options - to the interactive features - can be (*** soon ***)accessed from the menu in the top right of the screen. There are two switchable cameras available - a default "directors" camera that supports the story mode, and a user-manipulated "orbit" camera that can be toggled to at any time by either double tapping the screen (touchscreen) or by hitting the 'space' bar (on keyboard devices). The orbit camera allows you to use your touch screen or mouse to: zoom (pinch or mouse wheel scroll), pan (swipe or mouse click and drag) and an move (two finger swipe or mouse right click and dag) around the world.

Building the world. One moment please...
Serious play
Dreams and madness...

Welcome to the land of Kodam! Kodam is a peaceful little place where citizens go about their lives and activities much like we do in the 'real' world. They live in dwellings, mainly oncentrated in residential and urban settings. They farm fertile land and net the seas, to produce the food they eat and trade with others. They have built an industrialised supply chain that extracts and recycles materials so that they can manufacture the stuff they want. They transport themselves and the goods they need across long distances by road, rail, sea and air. And to support all of this, they produce and distribute the energy they need from a range of renewable and non-renewable sources.

It might be a little place, but there is a lot going on!

→
Models as toys

When you think about it, Kodam is really just a 'toy version' of a world you might recognise. This is a powerful idea because it means we can think of Kodam as a representation of our world: a kind of 'model world' featuring familiar components and connections.

We'll build on this idea of learning with a toy models to think about some seriously complex challenges. But first, it will be useful to understand how all the different parts of Kodam fit together in a dynamic yet organised system.

There are lots of ways to view and organise a system. Let's start by looking at some geographic areas of Kodam...

→
←
Take a look around

Use these options to take a quick tour of Kodam:

The big smoke

This dense urbanised area is considered the city centre. Here there is a high concentration of commercial buildings like offices, retail shops, hospitality and accommodation. Cities are also where other institutions like Government buildings, community centres, museums and galleries and hospitals are usually found. Its also common for people to live in cities, usually in more compact dwellings like townhouses and apartments.

The density of activity means that urban areas require a most energy during the day when workers and shoppers come in. Commercial buildings do use quite a lot of energy - particularly for powering refrigeration, lighting, and heating, cooling and ventilation (HVAC) services. Facilities like hospitals, which operate 24 hours a day with specialised equipment and HVAC requirements, tend to use even more energy, even on a per area basis.

Overall though, because there are so many commercial businesses in Kodam, the their buildings consume almost 30% of Kodam's total energy demand. This energy is mostly electricity, but also includes natural gas, and a bit some bottled LPG and firewood.

Transport: As the center of commerce the urban zone is also well linked to transport hubs and infrastructure that support private, public and freight transport by rail, air and sea.

Suburbia

Over here we have a built up, residential area. The landscape is dominated by rows of households, each with their own little plot of land. The are is more community and family orientated, and is surrounded by community institutions like schools, parklands, places of recreation and worship.

At home, citizens do just what we do at home. They store, prepare and cook using kitchen appliances (and then eat!) They keep themselves comfortable and clean, using appliances like air conditioners, fans, heaters, fireplaces, and hot water systems. They entertain themselves with TV screens and digital devices. They fill their bins with rubbish and recyclables, which get collected each week. They turn on lights in the evening so they can, well, keep doing what they want to do. And they also many other things at home, like sleep!

How much of these things each household does - the level of these activities - varies household to household, and is quite unique to the demographic of their occupants. Working couples and families with school children for example, tend to be unoccupied during the day, while elderly retired folk are more likely to be home more of the time. Big families and share houses will simply tend to just do more stuff, and also consume more. We can also see that homes come in different sizes, which is a bit of clue as to how many people might live in them.

There are however, quite a few important characteristics of homes that are hard to tell from the outside (at least in Kodam!). For example, the age of a home might interest because it can reveal clues about how it might have been constructed and with what materials and insulation. Its also hard to tell if the homes occupants own the home, or might be renting it. These might seem like like quite obtuse concerns right now, but they help us understand some technical limitations and willingness to improve the energy performance of these buildings. In these cases, we can better understand the thermal performance and opportunities improvement, and whether there are incentives for the owners and/or renters to invest in energy upgrades to the building.

The adults living in these homes often own a motor vehicle. In Kodam each home has on average, 1.5 cars! Cars are used to travel around: to work, school, the shops etc.

The food bowl

Agricultural land is used to farm crops, grains, fruits and vegetables, and to provide pasture for livestock to feed. Materials for textiles - like cotton and wool - are In Kodam we've got a variety of foods being farmed, as well as livestock like cattle, sheep, pigs and chickens. These aren't the only foods available in Kodam though - let's imagine that some of this produces gets exported to other lands, while Kodam imports many things they don't grow themselves.

While farmland mostly consists of fields and pastures, there are also buildings (typically barns and silos) that are used to house equipment like irrigation pumps and shelter smaller livestock, and to store farmed produce. Off road equipment like tractors and seeders might also be stored in these buildings, or parked nearby.

Agricultural land is an interesting case because while native vegetation has been cleared and converted (just like urban areas), the land itself is still relatively vast and spacious. This means there are opportunities for replanting some native vegetation in unused areas, or perhaps even to install equipment like on ground solar panels to generate energy.

The farmed soils also needs to be carefully managed to hold the nutrients and water required to grow produce. Soil carbon - storing carbon dioxide in soils - and regenerative agriculture are two practices that we'll consider further as farming practices that can help combat climate change.

Industrial zone

The industrial zone contains a real mix of different activities that tend to be geographically located on the outskirts of cities.

Industrial buildings are mostly factories and warehouses where things are made, and industrial processes occur. Manufacturing plants (aka factories) are where the goods we buy are made, packaged up and sent to retail stores or directly to consumers (usually via a wholesale warehouse). Depending on what they're making, these plants can vary in size and activity hugely!

Industrial processes can occur in these similar looking (at least in Kodam) 'industrial buildings', but have very specialised and often involve very energy intensive activities. Some prominent industries include the minerals, chemicals (including plastics), and metals industries that convert raw materials into materials that are used in the produces we buy. These industries, along the vast electronics industry, are important to consider in a model system because for most of us they are quite 'hidden' out of sight (just in front of those pesky extractive industries).

Another set of activity that we'll put under the 'industrial' umbrella are utilities like energy generation and distribution, water treatment and supply and waste treatment and disposal. Each of these utilities are essential services that service all of Kodam are attached to vast above and underground infrastructure.

Life aquatic

Like many settlements around the world, Kodam is situated next to the ocean. This not only makes for it a picturesque little place, but means that it is connected to a lot of different aquatic activities. An obviously recreational benefit is the beach, where folks can swim and play, and which might attract tourists to benefit the local economy.

Fishing is both a recreational and commercial activity that expands Kodam's food bowl to include all sorts of fish and crustaceans!

The ocean also provides access for ships that might carry freight or even passengers to other lands.

Closer to shore, the vastness of the ocean might also mean its possible to install clean energy infrastructure like offshore wind, or even some newer technologies like tidal energy. Blue carbon projects on coastal wetlands are another new and developing that could help to combat climate change.

Transport

Transport infrastructure is what connects all parts of Kodam, and what connects Kodam to other lands. This includes roads and rail lines the spread all around Kodam, and also extend to distance lands, as well sea ports and airports that are hubs for ships and planes.

Extractive industries

The extractive industries are essentially involve mining and drilling. Mines dig up all sorts of materials that are called ores: this includes metals, coal, oil shale, gemstones, limestone, chalk, dimension stone, rock salt, potash, gravel, and clay.

Renewable energy zone

One special area of focus is this nearby region where renewable energy is produced. Here we can see some wind turbines, a solar farm, a a hydroelectric power plant, and a big 'grid sized' battery.

These different energy sources do need some land and positioned where there's good wind, solar and waterway resource, but they don't need to be located next to each other. They do however, need to the located near electricity transmission lines, because they are built to feed electricity in grid so that electricity can be used by the citizens of Kodam.

Forgotten worlds?

As a reminder, Kodam is just a toy version of the real world. There are heaps of tings in the real world that aren't 'in' Kodam (at least yet). Some might be added in the future, but the point of a model (model world) is not to create a replica of the world, but to create a version that is representative, and that we can play around with to understand behaviour and opportunity.

The rationale for what appears in Kodam is that it includes the 'major' activities - those that contribute the 'material' emissions - while also illustrated how they are connected in a system. This means that there are often times where quite minor activities are shown (and modelled). Engineers and accountants might frown upon these added details, but in Kodam they provide the details area designed to provide context and connection to the real world.

Common people

Now that we a good idea of Kodam's geography, it's useful to know more about the types of characters, or 'actors' who live in Kodam. These are the folk that live in the those homes, work in those buildings, farm the land and travel around (amongst other things!).

Of course, every citizen is different - they are individuals or 'agents' who behave according their own desires and peculiarities - so its not really right to lump them together. But this is a toy we're talking about here, and it often makes sense to assume that there are some logical groups of people with similar characteristics and behaviours. A common way to do this is to describe groups of economic sectors or actors.

Activities: it's what we do!

We're going to come back to ways of organising the world when we talk more about the issue of climate change, because there are some specific emissions accounting categories that we'll need to understand. But right now we need to mention the simple but important concept of 'activities'. These are things we do and services we consume. We're going to carefully consider activities that are linked to greenhouse gas emissions: things like like turning on lights at home, driving a car to work, planting trees etc.

In the end we'll consider hundreds of unique activities that can be categorised and grouped in lots of different (and maybe confusing!) ways. But activities are what will make discussing climate actions seem familiar and real.

Time is critical because it lets us explore the 'dynamics' of the world. This will become clearer when we start to look into system behaviour (it's actually the concept time and 'delays' that shape how or whether our actions have the impact we might expect.) Ready to play!

As you can see, there's more to Kodam than meets the eye. Firstly, its not just a simple toy but a set of connected toys: more like a playground full of toys! Secondly we have a lot of different stuff in this playground, all our toys feature some shared characteristics and connections. Risk & impact
Why climate change matters

Despite all these interwoven activities and actors, the miniature world of Kodam seems to just 'works'. However just like the real world, Kodam can only exist in harmony with the natural environment and the climate system.

Unfortunately, many of those activities emit greenhouse gases that are causing climate change. But why does Kodam in particular need to worry about climate change? Let's start by introducing the concept of climate risk and explore how these risks affect the citizens of Kodam.

→
Climate risk

Climate risk is a tricky concept to explain because its easy confuse or conflate with a bunch of concepts like: natural hazards; event intensity, frequency and duration; shocks and stresses; exposure and vulnerability, and uncertainty... to name just a few.

We'll start by thinking of risk as being associated to an unwanted outcome that we can play out in Kodam. These tend to be physical outcomes that are triggered by unexpected 'shock' events, or from a build up of some kind of pressure, which we can think of as a stress. Some examples could be damage to a building after a windy storm or flood, or fire; or a reduced water supply and food production from a long drought.

→
←
Natural hazards

The events that trigger these unwanted consequences are called natural hazards. Many of these are affected by climate change, which is expected to cause more intense events and alter their duration and frequency. For example, scientists expect that some places will get more frequent and intense, short rainfall events (i.e. extreme storms), but experience less overall rain, leading to droughts.

We should be aware that not all natural hazards are influenced by climate change. And for some hazards, the link between climate change and more damaging outcomes is not as clear as others. Overall though, there is consensus that climate change is increasing risk. Let's now explore the natural hazards facing Kodam.

→
←
Warming-related hazards

Climate change is causing the average temperature in Kodam to rise

Tap on any of the hazards to see how they impact Kodam.

Hot days and heatwave

Hot days are those days when the temperature reaches 35 degrees. Very Hot days are those days when the temperate reaches 40 degrees. When this happens, people get stressed out, and we use a lot of energy to cool our homes and offices.

When there area series of hot days, usually for more than 3 days straight, we call this a heatwave. This is important because as humans, we tend to be able to cope with shorter events. A prolonged event however, causes...

Tap the Hot days and heatwave button again (or here) to change the intensity of the heat event.

Drought

Drought is a condition where there has a been a prolonged lack of rainfall, leading to to drying up of natural waterways and water supply. This is damaging to ecosystems, and the agricultural land and production

For most citizens of Kodam - those who are disconnected from the land - the agricultural impact is usually the first impact that's noticed. Farmers will course immediately notice a be impacted by water shortages and drier soils, particularly where they

The ecological damage of drought is just as devastating however natural systems will to some extent, adapt and evolve. Just think about how quickly the land regenerates and species return once a rainfall breaks a drought. That said, the conditions for drought are similar and intertwined with the phenomenon of desertification which has longer term affects.

Desertification

Bushfire

Bushfires are devastating fires that rapidly burn through native vegetation and land. They almost always start in rural areas (i.e. where there's more dense natural vegetation) but can spread and threaten rural areas with and even more built up areas.

Highly urban areas tend to be spared simply because of their distance to the bush, however bushfire smoke And yes, others categorise them as wildfires or forest fires...

Sea Level Rise

As the average temperature increases ice melts and more water fills the oceans. This causes the sea level to rise, albeit quite slowly. In Kodam, we can only see the mountainous ice caps melt, but in the real world ice melt is a much bigger problem in polar regions, and this affects the sea level everywhere.

Rising seas levels lead to coastal inundation. This puts coastal settlements at risk from flooding, which is problem because most major cities and settlements (including Kodam), are on the coast! Erosion?

Ocean acidification

Warming causes causes another serious problem in our oceans: it increases the acidity levels in the waters. This causing horrible impacts like coral bleaching, which is basically destroying aquatic ecosystems.

Ocean warming also causes all sorts of problems with the global Thermohaline circulation (THC) that connects and regualtes he worlds ocean system. Messing with fundamental ocean currents...

→
←
Storm-related hazards

Climate change is expected to trigger more intense storm and rainfall events in Kodam.

Tap on any of the hazards to see how they impact Kodam.

Storms and floods

Storms with intense or prolonged rainfall can cause flooding, particularly to low lying areas. Kodam's is pretty flat and near the ocean, so its mostly under threat from flooding events, but in real world there are areas more susceptible to rainfall and how water flows that are known as flood plains.

To cope with most rainfall, there are a series of surfaces gutters, drains and sewers that take rain water away, or even store that water in tanks and dams for us to use.

Flash flooding occurs when this water system is overwhelmed by very intense rainfall events, causing water to flood our roads and buildings.

Land and mudslides

Heavy rainfall events can also disrupt the stability of land and soils that are not used to being soaked with so much water. The loss in stability can be catastrophic in some regions and result in land and mud slides that can threaten urban areas.

Extreme wind events

Extreme wind events are also associated with storms and can cause damage to trees and built infrastructure. However, it should be pointed out that link between climate change and more intense or frequent extreme wind events is not as certain a say, temperature rise.

Tropical storm

Tropical storms are known by a few different names - a typhoon, hurricane or cyclone - depending on which ocean they develop from around world. We'll just call them tropical storms here in Kodam. These storms develop over the ocean and when they hit land, can cause enormous damage. However it should be pointed out that there is no consensus on the link between climate change and more intense or frequent tropical storms.

Understanding the impact of a hazard event

The impact or damage caused by hazard events is difficult to predict, measure and protect against. Let's consider the storm hazard. Climate chant is expected to affect a storms intensity and duration: and we can measure these in windspeed, rainfall and time etc. We are also expecting more frequent storm events, which can also try to predict and measure. So even though we don't know where storms will occur, we do expect more storms to hit Kodam.

In general, we can say that the citizens of Kodam are more exposed to storms, simply because of climate change. But frequency and intensity are not the only drivers of exposure.

→
←
Exposure to a hazard

We've seen that hazard frequency and intensity influence Kodam's exposure to a climate hazard. But we also need to worry about how many citizens and their built environment are exposed to the hazard. This is a closely linked to urban density, development and population growth - if more people, buildings and infrastructure are in the path of storm...well, we have more exposure. While the climate is certainly changing and causing more frequent hazard events, in many places, exploding urban growth is the main driver of exposure.

→
←
Vulnerability to a hazard

How well has Kodam planned and prepared for storm events? This is another complex consideration because it involves all sorts of planning and programs to minimise risks (i.e. exposure to hazards), which in turn is linked to economic development and wealth of the region or country (and their political will!). We can for example, protect ourselves from some physical damage from floods by investing in water and drainage infrastructure, or dykes. These are a kind of engineered resilience. However, engineering resilience becomes particularly costly when we try to protect ourselves and our assets from rare but extreme, high intensity hazard events.

We often refer to this as vulnerability, but as you might imagine, this is not easy to measure!

→
←
Types of impact and risk

We've focused more on the physical risk of damage so far, particularly to citizens and their built infrastructure. This is because they are much more direct and easy to visualise and understand, however there many flow on effects, influences and feedbacks to think about, particularly in social and ecological systems.

We might tackle this in a future version of Kodam (or link to some interesting resources)

→
←
Measuring impact or risk

In the meantime, we should mention that there is a more narrow measurement of climate risk that focuses physical assets and their value much like how is valued for insurance purposes. In a broader sense, its possible to identify and quantify some economic impacts on citizens that might occur from say, disruption and delays in transport (e.g. lost time at work), or increased energy usage or disruption to power (e.g. from increase air conditioning use or power failures). Proxy measures for impacts to human health - for example increase mortality rates or hospital visits from a heatwave - can also be introduced to better describe the real world impact of climate risk (note: avoid putting a economic $ value on a human life. Doing anything like that, is not helpful.)

→
←
Adaptation and resilience

We're almost there with all these climate change risk terms. Congratulations if you're still reading this!

This last couple we'll throw at you are two important ones that are often used to encapsulate a response to climate risk: climate change adaptation and climate resilience. Adaptation is pretty much exactly what the word suggests: its our ability cope with climate change. Because its something we want to improve, we often hear about our 'adaptive capacity'

Resilience (to climate change) is a pretty similar concept. Its perhaps a bit broader because we talk resilience as the capacity to bounce back from a disturbance, or even to bounce 'forward' (which is akin to 'building back better'). You'll also hear about resilience in a broader societal context where climate change is one of a range of issues that we want to build resilience to.

We'll talk a bit more about how we can adapt to climate change in the section on climate actions.

→
←
Emissions
Greenhouse gases cause climate change

To stop the climate from changing, we need to reduce our greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions . This because its these gases that stay in the earth's atmosphere - some years and many decades - and trap in heat and causes what call global warming.

Interestingly, the lengthy periods that GHGs stay in the atmosphere means that we've yet to see the climate change impacts of emissions we've already put in the air. At any moment we measure the amount of global GHGs in the atmosphere in parts per million (ppm) of carbon dioxide equivalent (we'll explain this in a moment). This is the concentration of global GHG emissions and reached 500ppm in 2019.

→
←
What are greenhouse gas emissions

There are a number of greenhouse gases, each with different 'global warming potential' (GWP), but the most common is carbon dioxide (CO2). Some other well known GHGs include methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N20), but we aggregate and measure the volume of GHG emissions in the equivalent GWP of carbon dioxide. You'll see GHGs reported in tonnes of CO2-e, and almost always on per annum basis. It's also become shorthand to just say 'carbon', but its really CO2-e we're talking about!

→
←
Counting carbons

Armed with a basic knowledge of the evils of carbon emissions, its important to understand how we measure and account for them. Carbon accounting helps to (again) provide common structure so that we better understand where emissions come from, and what can be done to reduce them.

The first concept we need to understand is that emissions we put into the atmosphere all come from somewhere: they all have a "source". But luckily, there are also ways to remove or draw down emissions from the atmosphere in what we call 'sinks'. There's a lots of sources and sinks, so before we look at individual sources and sinks, its useful to (again) organise them into what we commonly call 'emissions sectors'.

→
←
Emissions sectors

We can categorise all our emissions activity into six 'emissions sectors' that match how GHG inventories are constructed for countries (reporting to the IPCC) and places, under voluntary standards like the GHG Protocol for Cities. These sectors are titled: Stationary energy, Transport, Waste (and wastewater), Industrial processes and product use, Agriculture, and Forestry and land use.

You'll notice that these sectors don't really match same as the economic sectors we talked about earlier. This is a bit annoying, but its ok: its just another way to think about the world!

Now let's explore these sectors by identifying the emissions sources and sinks that belong to each one...

→

How can we see already reduced emissions?

Seeing all these balloons is kind of fascinating and hopefully a bit alarming! You've probably noticed that the balloons vary in size, which represents an estimate of the amount of GHGs are being emitted or removed from the atmosphere.

What isn't shown is how much carbon Kodam has avoided by adopting clean technologies and behaviours. These are different from 'sinks' because GHGs are never released into the atmosphere.

We call these 'switches' because it often involves switching a fuel source, or piece of technology to something with zero or less emissions than before. In our balloon world, we firstly need another colour! (And to reduce the size of our black balloons accordingly).

Emissions boundaries and "Scope"

We have an understanding of why emissions matter, where and who they're coming from, and how certain actions prevent, absorb and offset emissions. We're almost ready to play around with playing around with how we might get rid of these emissions and defeat climate change...yay!

But just before we do that, we need to address a couple of last, but very important concepts: the emissions 'boundary' and what accountants call emissions "Scope". These can be a little confusing but they are closely linked, so we'll talk about them together.

→
←
Setting the boundary

An emissions boundary is very much what it says on the tin: it defines what we include or exclude in a carbon inventory or footprint. Usually a boundary is something geographical like a country, state or local area; but a boundary can also be set around an organisation and their operations.

The purpose of a boundary is really to help define what emissions are being looked at, and by whom.

→
←
Emissions Scope

There are three emission Scopes: aptly named "Scope 1", "Scope 2" and "Scope 3".

  • Scope 1 emissions are what goes directly go into the atmosphere. An example when fuel is combusted and releases carbon dioxide.
  • Scope 2 emissions are associated with grid supplied electricity. It has its own Scope because electricity is many locations, so its useful to track the emissions to these locations, rather than lumping them all at say, the coal-fired power station.
  • Scope 3 emissions are associated with the supply of energy and some other 'out of boundary' emissions.

Having these definitions helps us assign emissions to who is really responsible for them, rather than a central service provider.

→
←
Avoiding double counting

In Kodam, the boundary includes everything you see. So technically, we could just look at Scope 1 emissions. However, as we now know, this doesn't give us a idea of where say, electricity is being demanded and used.

So to prevent double counting we might count Scope 2 emissions for everybody and not put a big balloon over the coal fired power station! Scope 3 emissions are a similar case. And for say waste emissions, we might prefer to place our balloons over each rubbish bin, rather than one big one over the landfill.

→
←
Climate action
Reducing emissions

In this section we're going to talk about how to reduce emissions in Kodam. We've seen that there are a lot of different emissions sources, and that they come from all over the economy. This means that there's also a lot of ways to reduce emissions!

We're going to look at some of the most practical actions that can reduce emissions in Kodam. And we're going to try and reduce our 'net emissions' way down to zero.

This stuff's going to involve some numbers (and costs) so we've got a few steps to get through

→
←
Baseline: an inventory of emissions today

If we're going to target emissions reduction we need to know how much we're emitting, and whether we've got any sinks that are helping to absorb emissions. This starting point is called the baseline.

In Kodam we just so happen to have an estimate of current emissions, all nicely classified and categorised into emissions sectors and sources, and by economic sectors and actors as well. But even more importantly, Kodam's carbon inventory has been broken down by a whole range of activities as well. Having an inventory like this makes the mathematical modelling of a system that we'll use possible!

→
←
Business as usual: a future without action

Reaching zero net emissions won't happen overnight, so we're going to need an estimate of what the inventory looks like in the future. But how long into the future? A good idea is to look out at least as far as we want to target reaching zero emissions. So let's say at least 10 years.

We do this so that we can estimate what emissions look like at our zero emissions target date, because there are good reasons to think Kodam's emissions will change (e.g. from population and business growth).

This pathway is called the business as usual (BaU) scenario because its an estimate of what future emissions will look like, if we didn't take action to reduce emissions.
